instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related study to evaluate the microbiological quality of chicken burgers?
Output: Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy and multi-spectral imaging (MSI) were used in the related study.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used inn the related study to evaluate the microbiological quality of chicken burgers?
Output: FTIR and MSI spectral feature processing methods were used in the related study to evaluate the microbiological quality of chicken burgers.

instruction: What metric was chosen for the classification models and how accurate were the results?
Output: The metric chosen for the classification models in the related study was accuracy. The accuracy scores for the external validation of the models were reported to be in the range of 79.41% to 89.71% for the FTIR data and 74.63% to 85.07% for the MSI data.

instruction: What machine learning approaches were used to train and test the classification models in the study evaluating the microbiological quality of chicken burgers using Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy and multi-spectral imaging (MSI) in tandem?
Output: The machine learning approaches used to train and test the classification models in the study were partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLSDA), support vector machine (SVM), random forest (RF), logistic regression (LR), and ordinal logistic regression (OLR).

instruction: How effective were the classification models in assessing the microbiological quality of chicken burgers using Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy and multi-spectral imaging (MSI) in tandem with machine learning algorithms?
Output: The classification models using Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy and multi-spectral imaging (MSI) in tandem with machine learning algorithms were found to be effective in assessing the microbiological quality of chicken burgers. The accuracy scores obtained for the external validation ranged from 79.41% to 89.71% for FTIR data and from 74.63% to 85.07% for MSI data. These results indicate that the models have merit in accurately classifying the microbiological quality groups of chicken burgers.
